Award.AwardTitle: Project Title: RAPID: Understanding the Experiences of Public Internet Users during the Novel Coronavirus Pandemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project addresses challenges faced by those who rely on public libraries for their computing needs and broadband Internet access. We see these individuals as disadvantaged by their life circumstances and as being digitally homeless. Without a residence from which they can reach the internet and have sufficient bandwidth, their computing lives are resource-limited, transient, less private, and less secure than those who access broadband from their residences. The novel coronavirus and COVID-19 pandemic has caused unprecedented disruption to life and brought new challenges to the lives of these individuals. The months-long shuttering of libraries has, in essence, evicted these users from their only space for broadband. These people cannot simply work from home or e-learn new skills, nor can their children shift to distance learning. The key questions we address are, how has the pandemic affected library Internet users? How have they adapted to the closure of facilities? Where did they turn for Internet access? How did libraries respond to help meet the needs of patrons? A better understanding on the experiences and needs of the digitally homeless during the current pandemic advances a number of societal benefits and socially relevant and desirable outcomes. Systematic, scientific knowledge will contribute to developing more informed strategies and policies to build a safe and secure cyber-infrastructure that is available to all.<br/><br/>As states begin the process of ending stay-at-home orders and libraries reopen, the PIs are collecting qualitative and quantitative retrospective information about what transpired during the quarantine and what is transpiring as states reopen. They are soliciting cooperation from library computer users at the local research site to complete a brief survey, and a subset to participate in field interviews. They also are generating a multi-stage cluster sample of library systems in the U.S. Team members are contacting selected libraries though phone or email to collect information on their experiences with the closures, how they did or did not provide open Internet access to the public, and what steps were taken to ensure secure and trustworthy access. The researchers are conducting a content analysis of news stories published during and after the pandemic regarding the experiences of Americans without internet access and how they coped during this time.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The disparities in broadband access is yet another dimension of social and economic inequality laid bare by the COVID-19 pandemic. With the closure of public libraries, those patrons who use the computers and internet therein were locked-out and left to fend for themselves. We conducted quick-response research to best capture the lived experiences of the digitally disadvantaged while these memories and incidents were still potent. There were three points of data collection. 

First, as some libraries re-opened in late 2020, we asked library computer users at one of our existing research sites to complete a brief survey (n=100) and, a subset, to participate in interviews (n=20). These users were likely to be men, generally economically poor, among them disproportionally people of color, with many experiencing homelessness. In contrast to the higher income earners in the sample, the lowest income group reported using the computer lab frequently before the pandemic and were also much more likely to have no other way of accessing the internet. After the reopening, library policies that reduced the opening hours, number of computers, and usage times negatively impacted these lower income earners the most. Most respondents told us that they were not concerned about contracting the virus in the library; in fact, for many of those experiencing homelessness, the COVID-19 precautions and extra cleaning efforts, actually provided a safer environment for them. Our results underscore that the library?s internet services are more of a necessity for lower income people and they were more likely negatively impacted by the pandemic.

Secondly, we generated a multi-stage sample (n=201) of libraries throughout the US permitting us to generalize findings to the entire country. We surveyed library directors on their experiences with the COVID-19 closures and how they adapted to the pandemic conditions once they reopened. We then combined these data with indicators from the 2019 Public Library Survey and the 2019 American Community Survey including the percentage of households living in poverty in the census tract where each library was located. We calculated the median poverty rate and those below we consider have ?higher poverty? and above the median ?lower poverty.? We found that most libraries we sampled removed computers to maximize social distancing; a strategy taken at the cost of limiting access to patrons who might not have their own devices. In fact, libraries in poorer neighborhoods were more likely to remove computers, with the average number removed higher (6.5) compared to their counterparts in wealthier neighborhoods (4.5). Libraries in both richer and poorer neighborhoods did not differ significantly in the number of Wi-Fi capable devices they added to their inventory after the pandemic. However, on average, libraries in more affluent areas received funding increases amounting to about 3.9% of their annual budgets compared to 2.6% for libraries in area with higher rates of poverty. School age children and adults of working age were particularly challenged by the pandemic?s effects on access. For students, not having internet access excluded them from educational opportunities as classes moved online and the pandemic left many adults unemployed and sometimes without the means to apply for unemployment or to search for new jobs. Our survey revealed some gaps in library directors? perceptions of success in addressing the needs of these two groups. For instance, more libraries in areas with less poverty indicated that they were ?very successful? or ?somewhat successful? at helping young children complete school requirements compared to libraries in higher poverty areas. Likewise, in terms of addressing adult patrons? needs for internet access, libraries in better-off areas were more likely to report being either ?very successful? or ?somewhat successful? compared to their counterparts in poorer areas. Finally, we found that libraries in areas with lower rates of poverty reported that, since the pandemic began, the number of patrons accessing the internet they provided increased either ?somewhat? or ?significantly? while a larger number of libraries in higher poverty areas indicated that this number of patrons decreased, either ?somewhat? or ?significantly.?

Finally, we conducted a content analysis of news stories (n=26) published during and after the pandemic specifically addressing the experiences of library patrons without broadband internet access at home and how they coped during these periods. Similar to the findings from our library interviews, the effects of the pandemic were not equally shared among social groups. Rural communities had the fewest options available even though there was a significant demand especially from families that were using remote schooling. Individuals that did not already have Wi-Fi capable devices were often left behind. Until the libraries reopened, there were few to no options for these individuals to access the internet. These news articles often reported calls from librarians for more funding to address community needs. Some reported that Federal stimulus funds were helpful but were seen as a temporary solution.
